title: Steven Universe - Off Colors
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Off Colors are a group of unaligned fugitive Gems (some of which are defective or "off color") who live reclusively in an abandoned Homeworld Kindergarten. This group includes Padparadscha, Rhodonite, the Rutile Twins and Fluorite (their presumed leader). After the events of "Lars' Head", this group is allied with Lars Barriga.

Members:

  • Padparadscha
  • Rutile Twins
  • Rhodonite
  • Fluorite

- Author's Note -

My complete set of Off Colors Gems is almost complete. I only need to complete Fluorite. But don't worry, she'll be available very soon.

Yes

Infill:

50%

description.text:
Now the new modular version. Compatible with orca v030 and (v040 with restrictions!), also with my x carriage derivate. E D I T : !!
Topperdel told me that i forgot that the "L" Holder was moved from back to front on V40, therefore i`m looking to make a new "L"-holder again that will fit backwards again Now with the more common 40mm fan (but not as good as with the radial fan :( )

Upper and middle part are the same for all, the lowerpart ring is for stock orca, the open lowerpart is for people using other x-carriage. Remove support from the upperpart. Mount the upperpart with a nylock screw and a springwasher.
The fan should only be mounted with one screw, so you can rotate it away for the first couple layers. The lower part is adjustable. All parts fit very tight to ensure they won`t fall apart while printing !

title: The Original VeNect Connector Quarter Inch Size
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The VeNect Connector is a Vector Equillibrium Intersection Point that quarter inch diameter rods and dowels can be inserted into. It can be used to build a tetrahedron (4 VeNects), a Vector Equillibrium (13 VeNects) or anything composed of the Isometric Vector Matrix Geometry.

The component is sized for any 1/4 diameter dowel or rod, but can be scaled down to accommodate things like tooth picks, and cotton swabs, or it can be scaled up to accommodate things like the shafts of ballpoint pens, or even larger for things like PVC Piping.

Included in this distribution are the original STL file that can be resized in any 3d software that supports the format, and a 3W file with added supports that is print ready on any printer that supports the format.

The insert points are intensionally a little loose. Add a single layer of tape to your dowel or rod, and you should get a snug fit. If you don't plan on ever taking apart your model, a small amount of hot glue also works pretty well.

I designed this solid in Blender3d which uses arbitrary units. Each "Unit" is supposed to correspond to 1 MM. If your software says the model is many meters across, just scale it down to 1/1000th the scale of what your software imported.

I have a passion for geometry, and a while back, I read Synergetics by Buckminster Fuller. Within a week of reading the book, I had the idea for the VeNect Connector. Then I got distracted by other projects and forgot about it for a while. Flash forward to May of 2017. The idea came back to my mind, so I designed a few prototypes in Blender3d, then went out and bought the cheapest 3d printer I could find. About 50 man hours, and 100 print hours later, I had a perfect VeNect Connector. Every aspect of the design other than the Vector Equilibrium geometry was informed by rough approximations of the phi ratio. I did this both for structural integrity, and aesthetic appeal. I am extremely happy with the final result, and now I am sharing it with the world!

-Baker Beltz

description.text: This is a simplified & stylized model that I made of the Dusable Bridge in Chicago. I left a lot of the details out to optimize it for 3D printing.
When I printed it, I printed two of the halves (with no raft & no supports) with the truss sticking upwards & glued them together in the center.

MY GIRLFRIEND IS DOING A Mara Jade costume and we needed the back harness, so after looking at pictures online, I decided to 3d model it. It is not 100% PERFECT! This is a close representation of the harness Mara Jade wears. It needs to be scaled to your size. It needs support, print at 20%, sand, fill and paint!

after this was built i compared it to a PDF sent to me by Carolyn from At Least I will web site, its not 100% like it but it did help verify i was really close with my model

Printer:

Folgertech FT5

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

20%

title: Parametric Danby Wine Cooler Foot Cup

description.text: I customized this to fit Danby Wine Cooler feet. Issue was that on padded carpet, the feet would sink in and prevent the door from opening as a sensor plate on bottom of door would drag against the carpet. Putting this cup over the feet extended the cooler up so door would open freely. description.text:
Added a cable chain mount to the quick fit carriage.

I have it located on the top left of the carriage, facing towards the front.

Thanks to the authors for making these great parts.

Seems like the cable chain mount is just close enough to help prevent the latch from rattling open if it were to loosen up. Bonus.

author: amarciri

description.text:
A souvenir from the German enclave in Switzerland bought, I believe, in the spring of 1970.  Simply carved, with visible cuts, it still gives a good impression of a rabbit.  If you look closely you will see that the rabbit is scratching itself with its right hind foot.
Two full size versions are provided, one is hollow with 1.4 mm walls.
On a Replicator the solid version, depending on infill, prints in about 90 minutes while the hollow version takes 75 minutes.

comments.text: Cute! Does the hollow version offer any benefit (e.g. support) over just printing the solid one with 0% infill?
comments.author: QuantumConcepts

author: amarciri

title: Customizable Case to recycle LCD Panel

description.text:
Note the reference of the LCD panel, and look for its characteristic on http://www.panelook.com
Notez la référence de la dalle LCD, et recherchez ses caractéristique sur http://www.panelook.com

Important features:
Caractéristique importantes:

  • Resolution (ex:1024x768, 1920x1080, ....)
  • Interface (LVDS, TTL)
  • power (3.3v, 5v, 12v)
    Alimentation (3.3v, 5v, 12v)
  • LVDS channel (single, dual)
    Canaux LVDS (1 ou 2)
  • LVDS width (6bits,8bits,10bits)
    Nombre de bits LVDS
  • LVDS connector (20 pins, 30pins, 40pin,...)
    Connecteur LVDS (20, 30, 40 broches)
  • backlight (LED, 1,2 or 4 CCFL)
    Rétroéclairage (LED, 1, 2, 3 ou 4 tubes fluo)

You need:
Vous avez besoin

  • Universal LCD controller board programmed for the resolution, voltage and lvds channel&width of the lcd panel (ex: v29, v56, pcb800099, NT68676, z.vst.3463.a1, ....)
    Contrôleur LCD universel programmé pour la résolution, le voltage et le nombre de bit et de canaux de l'interface LVDS
  • LVDS cable adapted to lvds channel&width (S6, D6, S8, or D8)
    Câble LVDS adapté aux nombre de canaux et de bits
  • if CCFL, inverter for 1, 2 or 4 CCFL
    un onduleur pour les tubes fluo
  • speaker
    haut parleur
  • power supply for LCD Controller
    Une alimentation pour le controleur LCD

Open the file in Openscad, and edit the variables.
Ouvrir le fichier dans Openscad, et éditer les variables.

To view, edit the Dxf variable to 0, and press the F5 key.
Pour visualiser, éditer la variable Dxf à 0, et appuyez sur la touche F5.

To create the DXF file, edit the Dxf variable to 2, press the F6 key, and export to DXF format (file> export> export as DXF)
Pour créer le fichier DXF, éditer la variable Dxf à 2, appuyer sur la touche F6, et exporter au format DXF (fichier > exporter > exporter comme DXF)

Cut the parts to the laser cutter, or to the CNC milling machine.
Découper les pièces à la découpeuse laser, ou à la fraiseuse CNC.

Assemble the pieces with wood glue, as in the pictures.
Assembler les pièces avec de la colle à bois, comme sur les photos.

Secure the LCD panel with small bits of wooden fall, as in the picture.
Caler la dalle LCD avec des petit bout de chute de bois, comme sur la photo.

Glue small pieces of cleat to the back, as shown in the picture.
Coller des petit morceau de tasseau à l’arrière, comme sur la photo.

title: ideas for the thesis, Solar Pannel, Solar traker
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a project that I made for a friend's thesis, It is a smal solar pannel controlled by arduino. It follow the sun with a pre installed sequence based on metereological station's data. It is an interessant project.

For CAD file

-BOX: http://microify.com/37Yp
-TOP BOX: http://microify.com/37ZG
-BOTTOM BOX: http://microify.com/37Yk
-T JUNCTION: http://microify.com/37ZY
-MOTOR JUNCTION: http://microify.com/37Zf
-PANNEL LOCK: http://microify.com/37Zk
-SUPPORT MOBILE: http://microify.com/37Zo
-SUPPORT LOCKED: http://microify.com/37Zm
After you had insert the tube, drill with a drill bit of 6mm

S

I've shared with you only the CAD design of the box, because if you need to resize you can do it. If you want all the CAD project contact me.
NGSS

Our local schools have added 3D printers in their business computer labs, but did not tell the teachers how they were supposed to be used.
I'm not a teacher, but every teacher i suppose can make a program by his self for this project. skils
  • Electnonics
  • c++ programmation
  • Manual Skills
  • So much commitment and interest
    • Duration Part one: Students learn about this technology. They need to understand how the solar panel can be useful for the future, and how this type of technology work. Part two: Students design a circuit for make work this project, using a open source system like arduino. Part three: Students print and realize their ones solar system.

step 1 Introduzione del funzionamento dei sistemi solari, come pregi e difetti. Nozioni sull'energia rinnovabile e cosa fare per migliorare l'ambiente. Introduzione dei sistemi solari intelligenti. Approfondimento sui sistemi follow sun. Step 2 Progettazione di un sistema solare autonomo, tenendo conto di latitudine e longitudine, durata della giornata ed intensità luminosa. Io non sono un professore ma sono un semplice studente che ha voluto condividere una tesina con gli altri. Quindi i professori che sono interessati a portare questo progetto nelle loro classi devono ingegnarsi a fare di questo progetto un opportunità per gli studenti. Di modo che sia possibile apprendere anche da un punto di vista pratico.

Material for mount
  • 6mm tube
  • 8mm tube
  • M3 Threaded bar
  • Glue "Attack"
  • Oil
  • 8mm bearing in 22 out
  • M3 Bolt
  • M3 Screw

• circuit
  • electronics
  • Manual Skills
  • c++ programmation
At least the ours of 3 months of laboratory.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Ich wollte eine etwas andere Handyhalterung für mein Fahrzeug haben. An der Windschutzscheibe gefällt mir die Halterung nicht, da immer wieder Abdrücke bleiben und die Halterung entweder im Sichtbereich ist oder das Handy nicht hineinpasst. Des Öfteren ist mir der Saugnapf auch schon abgefallen.
Also habe ich mir überlegt mir eine Halterung für den Becherhalter zu bauen.

Der runde Grundkörper lässt sich im Becherhalter drehen, womit ich die Position vom Handy schonmal sehr einfach ändern kann. Dann habe ich noch ein Gelenk hineinkonstruiert um den Winkel vom Handy anzupassen.

jetzt Version 2 da die erste Version schon nach einer Woche gerissen ist. Ich habe nun auch die Seiten etwas schmaler gemacht damit das Display nicht abgedeckt wird. Zudem ist die Schale etwas enger und hält das Handy nun besser.

In einer späteren Version werde ich mein Handy noch mit einer Qi- Ladespule ausstatten und einen Halter konstruieren, der eine Ladespule aufnimmt. Dann entfällt auch das ständige Kabelgewirr und Stecker ein und ausstecken.

English:
I wanted to have a different smartphone mount in my car than available. So I designed my own one. The holder is turnable inside the cup holder.
This is now a second version with tighter tolerances and a thicker walls as the first version broke after a week.
At the new version I also changed the thickness of the side mount so that the screen does not blocked by the holder.

Printer:

Mendel 90

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Ich habe mit einer 0,3mm Düse gedruckt.
Material ist PETG da es im Auto auch mal heißer werden kann.

I used a 0,3mm nozzle.
Material is PETG because of the higher temperature inside the car.

Noch benötigte Teile

2x M3x20mm DIN912
1x M3x30mm DIN912
1x M3 selflocking nut
2x M3 nut

Zum Konstruieren habe ich Autodesk Fusion 360 benutzt.
Falls jemand die Files haben möchte möge er mir eine PN schicken.

I used Fusion 360 for construction.
If somebody wants to have the original files please ask.

description.text: Stop letting your honeycomb table get in the way of your laser projects. The Lazor Blades are a type of small, modular, knife blade "puck" for your laser cutter, letting you move them around however you need for your project.

The Lazor Blades should hold any standard razor blades in its arms, but I have been using "Single Edge Scraper Blades", made by Allied, part number 64330. Basically, if your blades are meant to fit into safety scrapers, then they should be usable by Lazor Blades.
They have only been cut out of 1/8" MDF so far, so if you use another material, please leave feedback for others on what you experience. 
Since the piece fits about half-way up on the actual razor blade, it DOES get marred by the laser beam, but by the time the beam hits the Lazor Blade, the beam is unfocused enough to not cut through it (well, at least on my 40W laser). I personally see these as a consumable, since they can be reproduced quickly and easily.

comments.text: I tried using these cut from 1/8" acrylic, and the arms snapped off while trying to seat the blades.  :-\ I tried several times... it's just not flexible enough. Hardboard/MDF is probably the best material.
comments.author: stevecooley

comments.text: Made a derivative of these and posted it here on thingiverse. See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:40690http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... yea they may make you nervous and you may not want to use them in a production environment where you have not so bright people running the laser but if its your machine and you control the environment and you don't have kids to worry about I highly recommend these little guys. They make a huge difference. Not only can you see your work much more clearly but you don't have the edge of the honeycomb table to deal with either. Once you use them you wont want to go back to using the honeycomb table.

title: Low friction spool holder

description.text: A replacement spoolholder for the UM2 (or other printers if you create a different mount) which offers very little resistance when unspooling. Update: Added parts for 608 bearings and associated hardware. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O8T6kX7FJbM

In addition to the printed parts you will need:
  • 2x 626 bearings (cheap on Ebay)
  • 1x 6mm threaded rod, 95+mm long (better to cut after assembling to make sure)
  • 3x M6 nuts
    OR for the "608" parts:
  • 2x 608 bearings
  • 1x 8mm threaded rod, 95+mm long (better to cut after assembling to make sure)
  • 3x M8 nuts
    • Please note that I haven't printed and tested the 608 parts as I don't have the hardware for those at the moment.

Using Cura, go to advanced settings and activate "Horizontal Expansion" setting. Then type any value lower 0 in to compensate your tight holes. E.g. I'm using -0.15mm which is quite a lot, but prints come out perfectly scaled.
Changing this setting is way easier than remixing all things you want to print! :)

comments.text: The center thread is 32.6mm (for the 626) or 35.5mm ( 608 version).  I did a quick measurement and found Jet and MatterHackers filament spools have a center hole diameter of 33.5mm, Taulman "mini spools" are 19.5mm, GizmoDorks 55mm, MadeSolid 38mm, iC3D are 44mm, and MakerGeeks are 37mm.  In theory, the 626 version should work for all but Taulman spools, but it may be a tight fit.
comments.author: selmo

comments.text: Makerbot spools fit.  I have one spool but won't be buying again because of their high cost.  None of the other spools I have fit.  The OD of the threaded core is larger than most of the spools I've encountered.  Lately, I've been using Matterhacker filament and their hole is too small for the core.  They have two different hole sizes for the pro and standard materials, but both are much too small for this core diameter and both are too thick for the length of the core.  This has become my favorite spool size and is the same as Octave ABS spools.  I've also purchased T-PLA from Amazon, I believe it's Jet brand which has a large diameter hole but the spool is too thick so the length of the core is inadequate.  It's unfortunate spools vary so much.  I printed out this design without checking but have no use for it.  Threads fit very nice and so it will be used for show and tell.

description.text:
Simple educational robot for learning how to use various sensors (light, line, distance...) with Arduino UNO.
It features the CRM-Shield and a four-CNY70 board for reading a line on the floor.

Main features:
  • Two Pololu micro-motors with Pololu wheels
  • Pololu Ball caster
  • Arduino UNO with CRM-Shield (which has L298 motor driver, two LDR sensors and one LED).
  • Four-CNY70 board
  • This shield and CNY70 boards are very likely to be used in other printbots :)
  • 9V battery that connects to Arduino's power connector

title: Flexion Printrbot Simple Metal Adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Mount the Flexion extruder to the Printrbot Simple Metal with these adapters.

*These adapters are for the E3D version of the Flexion extruder.

*You must have the longer E3D Volcano or it may not reach the print bed.

*You must have a 1/4" mic6 aluminum print bed upgrade or the hot-end may not reach the bed.

UPDATE: Front Clip v6 has tighter tolerances and clamps tighter, but may be more difficult to install.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4ieej-1Pi_E

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.125

Infill:

50

Notes:

The threaded holes may not print well with larger layer heights.

Step 1

Get your E3D working with your Simple Metal, if you haven't already done so. There are many thorough guides on this procedure, search around.

http://thisoldspoon.blogspot.com/2015/03/e3d-v6-hotend-on-printrbot-simple-metal.html

https://matterhackers.dozuki.com/Guide/How+to+Install+an+E3D+v6+HotEnd+on+a+Printrbot+Simple+Metal/9

Step 2

Print the adapters and make sure the threaded holes will accept M3 bolts. The front clip requires two 16mm bolts minimum. The rear clip can be used with 6mm minimum up to 12mm max length.

Step 3

Raise the printer in Z to allow room to work on the extruder. TURN OFF THE PRINTER. Unbolt and remove the hot-end and extruder assembly and put aside. Unbolting the Y arm (6 bolts) will make the next steps easier, so unplug the cooling fan and Z sensor (note orientation: red to black).

Step 4

Mount the the Flexion upper assembly to the extruder motor. Get the mounting hardware knolled out and ready. Insert the E3D up through the extruder hole in the Y arm, then slide the Flexion E3D mounting block around the hot-end. Install the cover plate with two bolts into the extruder motor. Attach the rear clip first, then attach the front clip to secure the extruder to the Y arm.

Step 5

Bolt on the Y arm. Plug everything back in. Make sure to wire the hot-end cooling fan:

https://printrbot.zendesk.com/hc/en-us/articles/208320653-Ubis-13S-User-Manual

Adjust the Z probe to the appropriate distance. Calibrate Z height. Run a test print.

title: Power Tool Battery Adapter: Cordless to Corded Converter // Swap From Battery to Wall Outlet!

description.text:
Here's a little adapter I made so you can plug your cordless tools into the wall if you need more power! I had a spare 18V transformer lying around and used a female power connector that matched from my box of broken/spare electronics. You might need to wire up 2 outlets in parallel if you plan to do serious work (drilling/sawing). See youtube video here I made with glass:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rgWjTbx-aR8 1/4" quick disconnects (available at radioshack or online for pretty cheap) seem to fit the metal 'pins' perfectly. If you wire up the disconnects with 14 gauge wire you should be able to do 15A.

comments.text: I just finished an adapter that will allow you to use the inexpensive ($25-$30 on EBay) Bosch 18V lithium batteries with the Porter Cable 18V Power tools. I will post it as soon as I can.  It uses the electrical pins from your original (junk) NiCd pack.  When I discovered that the PC lithium packs were so expensive, it was a motivator to build the adapter!

description.text: This wallet was designed to be printed out of flexible filament. It holds up to five cards and has a slot on the back for cash. The slot holding the cards is tapered so the cards will not fall out. Also, the slot for cash is curved on one side to prevent the cash from falling out and it will flex outward as more bills are added.
This wallet was printed at a layer height of 0.2 mm, 2 perimeters, and 0.3 infill with sapphire NinjaFlex. Support material not necessary.

comments.text: this is the best 3d printed, flexible wallet on the site! Threw out my crappy leather wallet that fell apart and replaced it with this. After 3+ months of use (biking, walking, gym), zero issues, not a single thread loose and wallet kept its original shape. Its curve is designed to hug curvature of your leg and feels more natural than ordinary flat wallets.

print_settings.Notes:: At full size the 2 parts need to be printed separately on the MPSM.

description.text:
We were looking for a new hair catch and this design seemed like a compromise of what everyone wanted.

The original did not print correctly because the file uploaded to Thingiverse has damaged mesh.
When I repaired the mesh, I also shortened the bottom basket because it hit a crossbar in our pipe.

If you want this for a tub drain, scaling it in your slicer to about 80% seems to work fine.

Printer:

MP Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I just used my loaded PLA and default conditions and it seemed to come out fine.
If I reprint this, I would make it more solid probably.

At 80% scaling for the tub, the joint between the two parts is very stiff and feels like it might break. If you play with it for awhile or after it is in use with water running through it, it seems to be easier to open/close.

At full size the 2 parts need to be printed separately on the MPSM.

comments.text: I just made this and I love it! Thanks for creating it, it catches my hair instead of me having to dig down the drain. Thanks!!!

description.text:
Hate that you have to remove your normal case in order to put your phone in a vehicle case? I do too.

I saw @McNugget's motorcycle case on his Speed Triple and really liked the shade. It at least gives you a fighting chance of being able to see your screen. I created this case to put my iPhone6 with Tech21 case right inside. I used McNugget's idea for a shade. So far so good.

USE AT YOUR OWN RISK
Anytime you add an accessory on your bike, you're taking a risk. This one is on you. "If you get hemmed up, don't mention my name."

author: bs03

description.text:
Simple addons for stiffening the frame. this pieces will allow to triangulate the frame using some bolts and a M8 threaded rod.

the objective is had in mind was:
1) As little machine modification as possible
2) As simple and slim as possible

there are 2 types of addons:

The ones that get bolted to the 2020 frame, use tnuts, (considered for me the best and final design), they work with a couple of nuts , one trapped and one out of the piece ( see image) there is one for upper side and one for lower side, the upper side has an angle of 26.2 deg and the bottom one 90-26.2 (63.8) deg.

The other ones are designed to be mounted in the outer part of the frame, on the side. There are 2 versions , the one for the left side and the one (mirrored) for the right side.

i include the fusion360 files in order to get people change holes for using smaller rods or angles for adapting this to S4,S5 versions.

author: Modiano

description.text: Give-A-Beat and give back to the community.

This is an adapter in order to attach a cold shoe mount to a 1/4-20 threaded hole. This is useful for attaching camera accessories to a tripod, selfie stick, or other camera mounts which typically use 1/4-20 threads. I designed this to attach a microphone to a small mobile phone tripod, but it could be used to mount lights or anything else designed for a cold shoe mount.

Design Process

To research the dimensions required for a cold shoe mount, I downloaded various Thingiverse things as a reference since I did not have either side of a cold shoe mount when I designed this. I chose the dimensions from another user's creation that seemed the most reasonable. Onshape was used to design the part.

The countersunk hole for the 1/4-20 screw was created using OnShape's default hole feature. After printing, I purchased a countersunk SHCS from a local hardware store and mounted a microphone. Everything fit well.

A puzzle based on the work of Gregg Fleishman.   Print six copies to build the puzzle.  
Parametrically designed in OpenSCAD. Orginally designed for laser cutting.  
Now with updated tolerances for 3d printing!

To make a laser cut version change these lines...
s=2.7; //set s to scale to material thickness in mm
tol=0.2; //torlerance
projection(cut = false) scale([s,s,s]) bit(); //add the projection operation to create a 2d vector rather than 3d faces Finally, render (F6) and export as dxf.

author: Gtidave

description.text:
This is a bracket to mount a small 200mw VTX camera on a KingKong 90GT micro drone.

I knocked out a quick design before the camera arrived--I wanted to get it back in the air ASAP. I didn't realize the seven segment LED would be sticking out so far in the back, so I had to take a set of snips to the mount to get the camera to sit flush.

It works, and the rubber bands do a fantastic job of keeping the camera in place. They also allow the camera to get knocked over in a hard crash. I'm hoping that will help keep the antenna from getting too banged up or bent.

I plan to reshape the mount to fit better, but I figured I'd upload it now since it already works with a little modification!

title: Cork Pals: Fishy Fish
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Cork Pals are toys that utilize 3D printing and recycling. Use a wine cork to connect two 3D printed pieces and there you have it: Fishy Fish is swimming in your bathtub.
Fits over almost every wine cork.
Designed to be printed with PLA.
http://www.uauproject.com/?p=598

comments.text: Freaking adorable!
comments.author: Razor762

comments.text: I made this cork fish for a sink/float lesson for K-2nd graders.  They loved using the fish to explore buoyancy.
comments.author: mcnealwildcat

comments.text: Can you post each piece as a separate file so I can print each one in a different color quicker?
comments.author: AlexSchaffer1

comments.text: At this very moment I am printing one, and it looks really cool.
comments.author: jbs

comments.text: where are the rest of the Cork Pals?
comments.author: jbs

comments.text: Hey jbs, you can find more Cork Pals here : http://goo.gl/V3DxI2 and some more here: http://goo.gl/1dF6UK
comments.author: jbs

comments.text: since it is designed for PLA and ABS can be used do we need to scale up as ABS shrinks, or would the size be the same? thanks very cute
comments.author: Bluesmurf

comments.text: Hey, we designed it for PLA because it's a biodegredable material - it's only a thing of ecological choice. So if you like you can print it with ABS (it shouldnt shrink that much and should still fit most corks) but we encourage you to use PLA as a more eco friendly material :)
comments.author: Bluesmurf

comments.text: print with support.  maybe you could add a small breakaway part in the center to help with the overhang?
comments.author: slamzee

comments.text: awesome, i'll have to try this!  nice work.
comments.author: abletonfield

comments.text: Nice! I like the idea of recycling!
comments.author: Nesh

comments.text: Very Cool....Could be adapted for a roll of coins..:)
comments.author: Agwoan

comments.text: Cool idea there Agwoan.
comments.author: Agwoan

comments.text: Hey bkianian thanks for a kind word :) And to answer your Q: Of course you can print it with ABS, we print with PLA and encourage people to use it because it is an ecological bioplastic :)

comments.text: Nice little cute fishy! Well done with the cork!

title: Custom Switch for Fidget Cube Replica

description.text:
If you read the description of my fidget cube, you know that I got the wrong type of switch and needed to make one. If you didn't, you know now.

Fortunately, it uses the same 1mm bar that is used to hold the spinning gears in place on the side with the ball. Just cut it to the width of the base (add a little extra if you want it to be stiffer) and thread it through the switch. I am trying to figure out a way to incorporate the buttons from the 5-button side of the cube to give the switch a clicking effect. Feel free to make suggestions.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.05-.10

Infill:

100%

Notes:

The infill doesn't need to be as dense for the switch, just for the base (It's pretty slim).

title: Recycled Desktop Filament Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I'm typically running 4-5 spools on my desktop at a time for color changes, or if I'm running low on floss in the printer. I'm constantly knocking over the stack or the stack falls apart from printer vibration.

I came up with the idea of using an old wonky paper towel holder that I had. I fixed the wokiness, then removed the filddly bits. Presto. A mini Filament Stand is born.

Dedicated to my parents, Charley and Nancy. Thank you for great childhood, education, manners, and intellect.

author: dataman

title: LACK table printer hinge/ latch
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a latch/ hinge for converting a Ikea Lack table into a 3d printer enclosure, just print 3-4 of each part and install 2 as hinges and the other 1 or 2 as latches. There is a cut out on the back of one side meant for foamcore/ acrylic/ polybarbonate to be attached. The holes in the hinge plates are .125in across and the cut out is also .125in deep. It took about 5.5 hours to print all of the parts at .2mm.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

10%

I would recommend using a drill bit to make sure the hole is round and all supports are removed. Sanding should not be required if your machine is properly tuned with the exception of the top of the loops where depending on the layer height may scrape the other side.
I just needed some cheap and simple hinges, so I drew a couple designs on paper then tossed them together in solidworks.

comments.text: It would be of immense help if you were to show some pictures of a Lack table with these hinge/latches installed.  As it is - I'm not really certain how these would be used.
comments.author: bdormer

comments.text: I have now added a picture of how I have attached the latch, it isn't perfect but it works for my needs
comments.author: bdormer

comments.text:
I just uploaded the v2 wedge I actually used. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:428550
It's still not enough of a wedge for my application, but it does allow you to spin it around a bit so you can have the Skybell angle to the side and up. I have a 3D printer I used at the office, but you could always send it to Shapeways to have it printed. You could also make something pretty easy out of wood. title: Black and Decker Workmate replacement part gripper-updated 11-17-17

description.text:
I had destroyed a "Gripper" on my BD Workmate and decided to make a replacement. I ended up with two versions, one almost identical to the original and a second one with some reinforcements. 1-2-15 I loaded my repaired version as someone reported an issue.
Apr-4-17 Uploaded a double checked (repair) version with MM in the name. All models are saved in MM. 11-17-17 uploaded a redesigned version from Spaceclaim with smoother sides and some additional fillets. Latest file is BD Workmate Benchdog 11-17-17

Print this with 50% fill, wall thickness of two, with a raft and support, I set my bed temp on my Replicator to 110 degrees.  You should print it in a horizontal position.  The first time I printed it, I positioned it vertical to ensure the top looked nice.  The part came out great but with a single wall layer and 25% fill and the layers running horizontal, it was not strong enough when inserted into the workmate.  One of the "forks" cracked between layers right where it started.  I then changed the fill to 50% and set wall layers to 2 and printed it on its back (horizontal).  This did the trick and the part inserts and removes fine and holds up under pressure.  I also did a second design with a fillet fill on the inside of where the forks emerge from the cylinder to add extra strength.  I am uploading the Sketchup files and STL along with photos of the OEM part and my part.

comments.text: There is nothing wrong with the scale. It is saved in MM, check your slicer. I just downloaded it to check since it was uploaded long ago and loaded it into NetFabb to check size and it came in correct.  34.99x36x51 mm.  (1.38x1.42x 2.01 in.)   LxWxH
comments.author: MakerBeck

comments.text: Whats wrong with the scale settings on this I can hardly see it on my slicer?
comments.author: JaG_UK

comments.text: Great idea. Thanks.
comments.author: Ruffturn

comments.text: Hi, thanks for your work ! I have tried to print it but I have a problem in Simplify 3D, there is a triangle hole in the model.
comments.author: fabreax

comments.text: I loaded a repaired file in January 16 after you pointed out the problem.  Just checked it again and loaded another with MM on the end of the name to make it clear that the file is saved in MM (someone else said it was coming in micro sized to their slicer.)
comments.author: fabreax

comments.text: Four months later and these are holding up great on my Shop Mate work bench.
comments.author: MakerBeck

comments.text: I printed five of these so far.  Printing horizontally definitely works the best as far as strength because of the orientation of the layers prevents breaking of the flexible forks.  I also minimizes the support material that is printed vs the upright orientation.
comments.author: MakerBeck

(NOTE PRINT NOT TESTED IF PRINT IS WACKY PLEASE COMMENT TO TELL ME, SO I CAN FIX IT, Thank You) Full scale replica of the assault rifle Christopher Johnson uses in the sci-fi movie district 9 by Neill Blomkamp. I am personally a huge fan of the movie and wanted a full size alien rifle. I am still waiting to buy my own 3d printer but once I get it, this is going to be my favorite print (Most Likely) I have remixed this file from DrDanielThomas who has made a very lovely 3d model, but it was not to scale, so I made it up to scale and spilt it.

Note- For part FSTD, you need to print 24 if you plan on building the entire rifle. Thanks to
Talmorgoth for the advice.

title: Executor Greebled (Fixed, sliced 3x, whole) Starwars Super Star Destroyer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update 17.01.2018: I played around with greebling Jace1969's Executor and various other SSDs floating around the internet but was not able to produce results superior to SeraphsCoal's quickly so I abandoned that and went with brute force hole fixing. Due to inconsistent slicing results, I'm not going to upload those revisions for now. When I have time to play with 3d modeling again, I'll take another whack at fixing the defects of this beautiful model as I know I'll be printing more of them in the future. That said, the model is a completely acceptable non-professional quality print as is, it only takes a little bit of putty or scrap plastic to fix up before painting. On my 19.8% scale model, the only bits that have broken from intermittent handling is the very tips on the nose... so everything's holding up pretty well even with a pound of lead in it. See you again in a year's time!

Update 18.08.2017: Printed whole @ 12% scale with .25mm nozzle and abs+, side edge down with supports and print tabs. Holes printed in model where the internal dowel shafts resulted in the skin being too thin during slicing. Also too thin in front of bridge tower and engine shielding on the bottom of Part 03. Started investigating greebling with 3DS Max and the original Executor model by Jace1969 to fix thin skin and SeraphsCoal's frame defects. Will be a while before ready but I plan to apply techniques to other ships in the future as well.

Update 04.06.2017: Tweaked Lusankya parts
It'd be neat to have emblazons on the ship or stand for the other Executor classes. Like a hammer and a moon on the tail (top rear of part01) for Night Hammer (or more elegant insignia but as SSD's were intended as blatant symbols, eh). Thoughts, ideas, comments?

My list so far (http://www.theforce.net/swtc/ssdlist.html):
Executor
Lusankya (Rechristened in Rebel Starbird colors)
Reaper (Pentastar Alignment)
Intimidator
Brawl aka Iron Fist (gauntlet)
Razor's Kiss
Night Hammer aka Knight Hammer (black stealth hull, hammer and moon)
Terror
Aggressor
Guardian
Vengeance

Update 03.06.2017: Added reinforcement to part 02's engine nacelles.
Added Alliance Starbird insignia to part 03. http://starwars.wikia.com/wiki/Lusankya
I'm printing 3 part with a .25mm nozzle, .1mm layer height, 19.8% scale to fit Prusa i3 mk2. Meshmixer supports. Sliced with Slic3r. Cura had under extrusion on portions of the print. Front and rear thirds (parts 1&2 @ 15hr, 5&6 @ 20hr) printed fine but when I printed the middle (part 3&4 @125hr), pausing @ 113mm to add 540g of size 7 1/2 lead buckshot ballast + pva glue as a fixative, problems appeared.

First, there was a shell separation @ 113mm-113.3mm-ish running 1/2 of the way around and a resonance wave pattern appearing on another 1/4 of the shell from 113mm and up (too much weight? Belts not tight enough? Motor skipping?). There was also a bit of under-extrusion on a portion. The base also started to deform due to additional weight, heated bed and 90 hours of violent printing. To do again, I would print at .15 mm layer hight and print part 3 and 4 separately to add ballast to part 4 just before the top was printed. That or print part 3&4 as a piece, drill out holes in the base, fill with ballast and fill up with pva glue or epoxy. If you don't mess with pausing the print, part 3&4 should print just fine with a 6-8mm skirt.

Fixed Part 01's right edge (from rear view).
Combined parts for a 3 part print.
Combined parts to a whole image for smaller prints.
Remix of a Remix of Jace1969's 275cm Executor.
Overall length @ 100% is 275cm.

To Do: Design snug/snap fit nose guard for manipulation and travel protection. Form fit cardboard box insert? Try to fix excessive greebling of the flat bottom of part 04 (It looks ugly, is easy to manually remove with knife)

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.15 mm

Infill:

5% rectilinear or 8-10% grid for ballast, 5-10% cubic otherwise

Notes:

Printed 3 sections with .25 mm nozzle. @ .1 mm layer height overall and .05 mm over the Rebel symbol of the Lusankya model. Extra detail was not worth time @ 19.8 scale. Added ballast mid way up part 3&4 caused printing defects. Used a lot of Meshmixer supports which has become a great deal of work to prune in Meshmixer and remove after printing. You can consider printing without supports, cutting out droopy sections and adding back custom panels where needed. 5% rectilinear infill let pva glue seep throughout model internals. 2 shells was insufficient for 500+g of ballast but just fine without.

Next time: Will print @ 25-30% of original scale in 6 sections @ .15 mm. 2 shells on all sides except for section that gets ballast which will have 3 or 4 shells on all sides. Will drill out holes in flat face of section's connecting area to add lead then superglue a funnel to the hole and top off the section with pva glue.

Yeah, adding ballast for a display piece would be silly but if you're planning on handling it at all, the extra weight makes it feel much more expensive and substantial. Sealing the paint job with XTC-3D or a good clear coat should be a consideration for protection and strengthening.

author: Verskon

description.text:
Guardian Robot

After printing the Maker Figure my son and I sat down to design our own robot. During our concept generation session it quickly became apparent that my son, who is four, was asking me to design a robot that looked very similar to one from a video game he had seen. With that drawing as a template we built a few prototypes of the body and legs before settling on the parts that have been uploaded. According to my son, "It's perfect, exactly what I wanted." We hope the maker community enjoys it as well.

Community

  • Sonoranguy Modified the feet to remove the rotating claws. The rotating claws can be flimsy which this would fix.
  • Guardian Leg Segment Check out this improved version of the guardian leg. It no long snaps in, but looks much closer to the original.
  • Geirskogul Do not use carbon or transparent ABS for the leg segments. Transparent ABS has acrylic in it and it too brittle.

Remixes

  • Hackable - This remix provides a bunch of space and hooks for electronics such as LEDs and servos.
  • Details Separate - This separates the details and the robot body to allow for dual extrusion printing.

Inspiration

The PCB Workstation with Articulating Arms provided the inspiration for the robot arms.

Design

My goal was to print the robot in as few parts as possible while ensuring that all of the joints printed cleanly.

Body

I kept kept the hip joints as part of the body, even though the resulting hips were looser then desired, because I liked the integrated design and the challenge of printing everything in a single shot. The head rotates in the same manner as the Maker Faire bot. To improve print time and material usage, I hollowed out the model being careful to minimize overhangs. Most of the model has wall thicknesses of 2-3 mm where possible.

Arms

The arms took a few tries to get right. I ended up printing the arm segments separately so that the sections could be snapped in for a tighter fit than would be possible if they were printed in a single shot. Finding appropriate dimensions for the engagement required trial and error to find segments that did not fall apart easily and still rotated smoothly. Variables to consider here were the wall thickness, engagement depth, and ball diameter. The claws use simple cone hinges providing smooth motion.

To Print

Print 1 Body, 6 Claws, and 90 Segments.

I used a raft and no support to build these parts. The Segment is printed with the ball rotated to be on top and the Claw is rotated to be printed with the claw on the bottom. Print the body with the head rotated to be on top.

Once printed, the head and hip joints rotated smoothly with minimal sticking.

Optional Files

I've uploaded body_120dia_botwg which should allow the Guardian to be printed on a bed with dimensions of 120 x 120 x 120. This was modified by cutting a small portion off the OD of the original.

Caution

Reducing the size may cause the parts to freeze or prove brittle. I used a minimal gap to allow the parts to rotate and a minimal wall thickness to conserve material.

Future Work

As with any project, there is always more to do an improve upon. Here is a my current list.

  • Complete I left the arms hollow for the potential to add a string or elastic band.
  • Complete Increase the claw size (almost double).
  • Complete Create a model with snap in hip joints to provide more friction. [I built this and it worked... however the model required significant tweaking from standard print settings. In order to keep this easy to print, I removed this feature. You can freeze the hips in place with a dab of super glue.]
  • Complete Add an access hatch to the head and or base for electronics (LEDs) See this remix.
  • I need to redesign the claws to be more robust. The current hinge fails to easily.

description.text:
WORK IN PROGRESS

This is mikobot. My small work in progress developement platform.
I was inspired by timmiclark and his ProtoTank https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:972768

I used M4 screws and nuts to put the bot together. There are 2 decks. One is used for Raspberry Pi only and the other is used for Arduino Mega.

At the moment I use a Carson RC Controller with 5 Channels to control it. Switchable to autonomous mode using the IR sensor ziptied to the front. (Yes I was lazy) Wheels and the rear ball are taken from a original Arduino Robot (The round expensive thing).

Future plans: put it on tracks or steppers. add more sensors or switches, maybe use Raspberry Pi if I can find a motor hat. Add a camera.

If you like this and want to make a remix or add some things I will be happy to share files if needed.

title: Vertical Stab Fences for 2M F3A Aircraft

description.text:
An alternative to the T-Canalyzer, these fences straighten airflow over the fin to improve knife-edge flight so important in modern FAI aerobatic sequences. Research by Voicu available at http://www.rcuniverse.com/forum/rc-pattern-flying-101/11585841-airflow-visualisation.html

Fences shown here are based on my copies of Voicu's per his photos on above link. Photo shown here is of my BJ Prolog, a slightly older design brought up to modern F3A requirements. Shown aircraft will perform very tight knife-edge loops.

As shown, the fences may fit other 2M BJ pattern aircraft, as his designs are often derivative. Even if they do not fit your plane, they may serve as a reference point for your own variation.

Additional notes:

  1. Four fences total are required, two upper and two lower.
  2. Prints shown are 2mm in thickness, but this could be increased to 3mm if additional stiffness is desired. IMHO, 2mm PLA should work perfectly fine.
  3. Incidence of the fences is identical to that of the horizontal stab.
  4. The tail of each fence ends at the back of the tail post.
  5. Do not modify the fences to wrap around the leading edge of any swept surface. Voicu found that it countered the effectiveness due to induced turbulence. (I know you see this on other planes. Don't fall for it!)
  6. Originals shown here are cut from 1mm fiberglass sheet. If you wish to duplicate them in glass or another material, prints here can serve as templates.
  7. Mine have additional support by slotted brass tubing inserted in holes drilled through the fin. Fences are edge glued with epoxy. My original tests were with cut styrene taped in place before changing to the permanent installation shown.

Design steps

Original fiberglass parts were scanned and traced using Visio.
DXF file was exported from Visio and imported to Autodesk Fusion 360. Extrusion was performed in Fusion and STL generated.
This STL was passed through openscad for future use.

description.text: Fairly accurate model of a Boeing 737 300 series. Modeled using CAD elevations from Boeing's website: http://www.boeing.com/commercial/airports/3_view.html

Some of these pieces may be too tall for a standard makerbot.  Scale it or slice it if you need to.  There are holes for alignment on some parts using small pieces of 3mm filament.  Landing gear struts are 3mm filament as well.  Note the asymmetrical engine nacelles.  
The model is a little tail heavy, so you might want to glue a penny in the nose section so it sits on the ground properly.  
Update 2013.08.10:  Rebuilt the front fuselage to fix Slic3r errors.  Use Frontfuselage3.stl

I've started using the 3DBenchy model to test new filaments. After printing, I wanted to keep them displayed somewhere easy to see, and be able to keep some notes on what the materials and print settings were. I liked the carousel and rudder stand holders, but I don't have much tabletop space to store them. I do have a large section of pegboard, so I created this four-part holder to display them next to my printer.

The clips are sized for "small" pegboard holes, which are approximately 4.4mm in diameter. The top, hooked end should slip easily into the hole, but the bottom ends of the clips should be tight when pressed into the pegboard, so that it can support the weight of the boat. Larger pegboard holes won't support the holder as securely. I'm hoping to add larger clips in future.

The "label" piece is sized to allow a strip of painters or masking tape to be added, so that notes can be written about the piece being displayed.

The pieces can be assembled prior to inserting into the pegboard, or assembled on the board directly. The tolerances should allow the pieces to fit together snugly, but some minor scaling might be needed if they're too loose. I suggest printing in PETG if possible, to prevent shrinking but retain some flexibility to keep it from cracking. The infill percent shouldn't matter for the boat holder or label components. If you need more strength from the clips, or can't use PETG, they can be printed with a higher infill setting.

A polargraph drawing machine can draw practically anything you want. Get it to work properly, and you can create endless designs, patterns, or drawings without having to produce any artwork yourself. For artistically challenged people (like me!), this is the perfect way to unlock your creative abilities without having to worry about hand coordination. Even if you possess this talent, you can use a polargraph drawing machine to produce a very unique style of art.

To view detailed, step-by-step instructions, visit my documentation website: https://sites.google.com/a/cshnyc.org/boorady-documentation/

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No
NGSS CCSS

This page will give you the tools you need to create your own polargraph drawing machine. This is based off of an Instructable by Euphy (see References) and includes a description of my own process when creating this machine.

About the Machine Although "polargraph" has caught on as a term for any hanging-v plotter drawbots, the term actually describes a drawing machine that specifically uses the polargraph software, which uses the dual-polar coordinate system instead of the cartesian system. There are hundreds of ways to assemble a polargraph machine, and even more ways to make your own drawbot, but my machine is based off of the original polargraph model. To read more about polargraphs, visit this site: http://www.polargraph.co.uk/whats-a-polargraph/

To make this, you will need a board or flat surface to work with, 1 beaded chord, 2 stepper motors, 1 servo motor, 2 sprockets, 1 gondola pen holder, 1 Arduino, 1 motorshield, 1 5V power supply, 3 small weights, 1 USB cable, and a computer.
15-20 hours

Step by Step Instructions There are two main components of this process: the software setup and the actual machine setup. Below is a general overview of the steps I took to create this, but a more detailed version is on my documentation site (see References). Machine Setup:
1) 3D print the sprockets and gondola from Thingiverse
2) Add the beaded chord to the gondola
3) Using velcro, attach the motors to opposite sides of the top of your board
4) Connect the two motors to your motorshield (and plug the motorshield into the Arduino)
5) Add counterweights to the gondola and both ends of the beaded chord
6) Using velcro, attach your servo to the gondola, extend the wires, and plug it into your motorshield
7) Stick a pen into the gondola, plug a 5V power source into your Arduino, use a USB cable to connect your Arduino to your computer, and download the software: Software:
1) Make sure you have the Arduino software and Processing 2.2.1
2) Download the Arduino source code. It should be the one titled "Source code (zip)": https://github.com/euphy/polargraphcontroller/releases/tag/2017-05-10-23-30
3) Download the Processing source code. It should be the one titled "Polargraph.2017-05-10.zip": https://github.com/euphy/polargraphcontroller/releases/tag/2017-05-10-23-30
4) Compile & upload the Arduino code, and run the Processing code. A new Java based "Polargraphcontroller" app should pop up as soon as you run Processing
5) Plug your machine measurements into the Setup tab of the Polargraphcontroller
6) Upload an image file (along with a vector file), adjust the settings, click "render pixels," and watch it work its magic!

To construct my machine, I used this Instructable: http://www.instructables.com/id/Polargraph-Drawing-Machine/ And these Things:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:19690
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:472573 I then created a Google Site documenting my own process, failures, and successes: https://sites.google.com/a/cshnyc.org/boorady-documentation/

remixed_from.author: Silverquark
remixed_from.title: TUSH - The Ultimate Spool Holder - with clips for Wanho Duplicator i3 Plus

title: TUSH - The Ultimate Spool Holder (parametric) - w/ clips and M3 bolts for Wanho Duplicator i3 / Maker Select

description.text:
I've updated the design to be a little more forgiving on the bearing fit (hopefully).

A parametric remix on the TUSH with clips for use with other upgrades (e.g. filament guides). I also changed the assembly to be with two M3x12 bolts and nuts (per side) which seems to be a little sturdier.

Plus, my print failed about 50% through (Y-axis was bumped) and it still was a functional print because of the bolts instead of using a friction fit.

STLs are for use with the "Wanhao i3 Maker Select Filament Guide and Riser v4" (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1598317) which caused the filament roll to lift off the bearings of the stock design. I know I could have removed the stock spool holder, but it's a nice insurance and it's one more thing I don't need to store in a box.

If you have a different scenario you plan to use this, I've also included the Fusion 360 files to modify the design as needed.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select v2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Raft is unnecessary. Supports are only needed for the bolt and nut holes (your call if your printer needs them). Infill / resolution doesn't matter, but don't tighten the bolts too much if you do a lower percentage.

Required Hardware

4x - 608 Bearings (cheap is fine)
4x - M3x12 Hex Cap Screws
4x - M3 Nuts

Remodeled into Fusion 360

I grabbed dimensions from the SketchUp file (provided by Silverquark) and modeled it in Fusion 360 (with variables). This is ultimately the reason I switched from SketchUp in the first place (parametric designs).
